Comment: Perhaps hoping to draw his opponent into a Ruy Lopez, where Canal's own theoretical innovation is now immortalized as the Canal Variation.
The amateur starts the fireworks immediately, choosing the aggressive, if not entirely theoretically sound, Center Counter Defense.
The natural move.
The immediate recapture, exposing the Queen to danger.
Development with gain of time, attacking the Queen.
The usual move, setting up a potential pin on the White QN.
Canal's move activates the pin but seizes central space.
Creating a potential line of retreat for the Q.
Canal resumes his development and guards the QP.
The amateur develops another piece and establishes a second pin.
Canal seizes an open diagonal for his Bishop.
The amateur opens a diagonal for the development of *his* Bishop.
Canal "puts the question"...
...and gets an answer.
Canal completes the exchange and clears the way for potential Q-side castling.
The amateur develops a piece and adds force to the pin on the QN.
Canal clears the last minor piece off his first rank.
The amateur prepares to castle Queen-side.
Now Canal "puts the question" to the other Black Bishop.
The amateur sees that 11 PxB can be answered by 11...QxR ch, and ignores the threat in favor of castling.
